keyTakeAways: A former New York state prison guard, David Kingsley, was found guilty of murder and first-degree manslaughter in the beating of inmate Robert Brooks, who died after being pummeled while handcuffed.

Two other guards, Mathew Galliher and Nicholas Kieffer, were acquitted of murder charges despite being charged with first-degree manslaughter and second-degree gang assault, with Kieffer also facing a false instrument charge.
The body-camera footage, though silent, showed guards violently attacking Brooks, including stomping, punching, and lifting him by the neck, and was central to the prosecution's case.

Prosecutors argued that all guards acted as a gang and showed a depraved indifference to human life, with William Fitzpatrick, the special prosecutor, asserting that the group collectively killed Brooks.
Brooks had been serving a 12-year sentence for first-degree assault since 2017 and was transferred to Marcy Correctional Facility on the night of the incident.
Six of the 10 guards indicted in February were charged with murder, with five pleading guilty to manslaughter and one to a misdemeanor charge of attempted tampering with evidence.
Three more guards have agreed to plead guilty to reduced charges and are cooperating with prosecutors, including two who testified at trial.

William Fitzpatrick, who took over as special prosecutor after Attorney General Letitia James recused herself, is also prosecuting guards involved in the March 1 beating of Messiah Nantwi at Mid-State Correctional Facility.
The case has sparked public outrage due to the graphic nature of the video footage and raises broader concerns about prison violence and accountability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A former New York state prison guard, David Kingsley, was found guilty of murder and first-degree manslaughter in the fatal beating of inmate Robert Brooks, who was attacked multiple times upon arrival at Marcy Correctional Facility on December 9, 2024. The body-camera footage, showing guards punching, stomping, and lifting Brooks by the neck, was pivotal in the prosecutionâ€™s case. While Kingsley was convicted, guards Mathew Galliher and Nicholas Kieffer were acquitted of murder charges, though both faced lesser charges. The case revealed a pattern of systemic violence in correctional facilities, with prosecutors arguing that the guards acted as a gang with depraved indifference to human life. The prosecution, led by special prosecutor William Fitzpatrick, also includes ongoing cases involving the beating of Messiah Nantwi at Mid-State Correctional Facility, highlighting a broader crisis in prison guard accountability and inmate safety.
